newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK stocks jump to strong close as HK Tel surges.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks jump to strong close as HK Tel surges.

text.p: A late rally pushed Hong Kong stocks to a sharply higher close on Thursday, bolstered by a surge in Hongkong Telecom as investors speculated on a deal with a China partner and welcomed the firm's year earnings.
The Hang Seng Index rose 134.39 points, or 0.99 percent, to 13,740.30, wiping out an early loss of 158.43 points.

"It's predominantly led by Telecom," said Miles Remington, sales trader at SocGen-Crosby Securities. "China involvement is being rumoured across the board there, which must be taken as positive and that is why people are buying."
Hongkong Telecom jumped HK$0.80 to HK$15.00.
The stock rose to its highest level in almost a year on Thursday, reaching a session high of HK$15.05.
"It's short-term speculation," said Geoff Galbraith in institutional sales at Nava SC Securities. "I think Telecom is going to run into some profit-taking."
The Hong Kong utility announced a rise of 12.5 percent in net profit for the year to March 31 to HK$11.18 billion during the afternoon, slightly better than analysts had expected.
Brokers said warrant-related activity had also pushed Hongkong Telecom shares higher.
Thursday's session was the seventh winning day in a row for the Hang Seng, bringing the blue-chip index to its highest point since its record close of 13,868.24 on January 20.
Turnover was a strong HK$14.04 billion compared with HK$14.76 billion on Wednesday.
"It's just short-term momentum and liquidity. You would never know Wall Street was down overnight," said Galbraith.

A 139.67-point fall in the Dow industrials on Wednesday to 7,085.65 helped contribute to the market's early weakness. But a record high in HSBC Holdings Plc shares allowed the Hang Seng Index to wipe out its initial losses.
HSBC shares closed at HK$210.00, up HK$3.00, after reaching an all-time high of HK$211.00 during the session.
"We have already revised our target price to HK$230 for the end of the year," said Edward Chan, head of research at Amsteel Securities, adding that he had a previous target of HK$206.
Some property developers moved ahead, with New World Development Co Ltd adding HK$1.20 to HK$48.90 and Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd gaining HK$0.25 to HK$73.75.
Analysts said the Hang Seng Index could trade in a range in coming days after rising 1,139.88 points, or 9.05 percent, over the last seven sessions.
